nxr.tpad.lib

Interface TPad

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    TPadImpl

    public interface TPad
    This interface provides the basic TPad functions

    All TPad enabled Android Applications must use this class to interface with the TPad. The TPad itself is managed through the usage of the TPadService, which runs in the background and manages the connection of the phone to the TPad electronics board. Typical usage: 

     (Load TPad on startup)
 TPad tpad = new TPadImpl(this);
 
 (Set friction value to half total value)
 tpad.sendFriction(0.5f);
 
 (disconnect TPad when activity is destroyed)
 tpad.disconnectTPad();

    • Method Detail

      • sendFriction

        void sendFriction(float f)
        Send new friction level value to TPad

        The TPad can change the level of friction between the user's finger and the screen. Calling this function will set a new level of friction on the output of the TPad screen.

        Note that a value of 1 will turn the TPad on to full power, so be careful leaving the screen on for long periods of time, or when the user is not touching the screen.

        Parameters:
        f - Friction level to be output to the screen. 1 corresponds to lowest friction possible (slipperiest screen, turns TPad fully on) 0 corresponds to highest friction possible (stickiest screen, turns TPad off!) Any value in-between 0 and 1 will be proportionally sticky or slippery

      • sendFrictionBuffer

        void sendFrictionBuffer(float[] buffArray)
        Send a buffer of friction values to be streamed to the TPad

        Same as sendFriction(float f), but with a large buffer of friction values. Friction values will be played back to the TPad at a rate of TPadService.OUTPUT_SAMPLE_RATE.

        For example: For a TPad that is playing back values at 6250 Hz, an array of 625 values will be played for 100 mS. The internal #TPadService buffer can, however, only hold enough data to be played back for 1 second. For longer playback times, send data to the Service in chunks of less than a second.

        For best user experience, it is recommended to send data to the TPad as fast as possible. Therefore, you should send friction buffer chunks to the TPad every 10mS or so.

        Note that a value of 1 will turn the TPad on to full power, so be careful leaving the screen on for long periods of time, or when the user is not touching the screen.

        Parameters:
        buffArray - The array of friction values to be sent to the TPad and played back at the output sample rate. Any new calls to sendFrictionBuffer will overwrite what is currently in the buffer to playback.

      • sendVibration

        void sendVibration(int type,
                   float freq,
                   float amp)
        Start a vibration to be played to the output of the TPad.

        This function will output a single freqeuncy vibration-like signal to the TPad surface when called. The vibration will continue to play unless overwritten by another TPad command, or the TPad is turned off.

        The type of stimulus this gives to the user is, in general, very similar to the onboard vibration motor that is common in most phones. With the TPad, however, this stimulus is felt directly on the fingertip, and not throughout the entire phone.

        In general, this type of feedback is NOT what the TPad is specifically designed for, but it is possible to do. In most cases, it is recommended you use the TPad to change overall friction value on the screen using sendFriction(float f), sendFrictionBuffer(float[] buffArray), or a FrictionMapView; *

        Parameters:
        type - Vibration waveform to be played. See TPadVibration for choices
        freq - Frequency of vibration waveform in Hz. Generally, use 0-1000Hz, and 200Hz for 'strongest' stimulus.
        amp - Overall amplitude (strength) of vibration. 0 is none, 1 is full.

      • turnOff

        void turnOff()
        Turns TPad off

        Same as sending a 0 friction value. See sendFriction(float f)

      • refreshFreq

        void refreshFreq()

      • refreshScale

        void refreshScale()

      • sendNewFreq

        void sendNewFreq(int f)
        Tell TPad to operate at new carrier frequency

        Each TPad must operate at a specific frequency in order to get the highest level of friction reduction. This frequency is unique to each TPad, but generally in the 30,000 Hz range.

        Parameters:
        freq - Carrier Frequency to change to (in Hz)

      • disconnectTPad

        void disconnectTPad()
        Unbind from TPad Connect Service

        Call this function when you are finished using the TPad for good. I.E. in the onDestroy() callback of the Activity class.
